changes.diff:
Line 288: Line 288:
==Impact==
==Impact==
Within UTCs, SB 79 is set to overturn or undermine local laws and propositions which restrict density levels, such as [[Proposition U]], a 1986 [[Los Angeles]] ballot initiative which limited allowable residential density outside of [[Downtown Los Angeles]] by half.<ref name=":03">{{Cite journal |last=Severen |first=Christopher |date=2023 |title=Commuting, Labor, and Housing Market Effects of Mass Transportation: Welfare and Identification |url=https://www.philadelphiafed.org/-/media/frbp/assets/working-papers/2018/wp18-14r.pdf |journal=Review of Economics and Statistics |volume=105 |issue=5 |pages=1073–1091 |doi=10.1162/rest_a_01100 |issn=0034-6535}}</ref> The law's immediate impact was not expected by commentators to blunt the effects of contemporary economic deterrence to housing construction (i.e. [[Tariffs in the second Trump administration]]), but to potentially take advantage of future market improvements favorable to construction in order to bring down the costs of housing and living.<ref>{{Cite news |last=Christopher |first=Ben |date=2025-10-10 |title=Gavin Newsom signs law overhauling local zoning to build more housing |url=https://calmatters.org/housing/2025/10/newsom-signs-massive-california-housing-overhaul/ |access-date=2025-10-13 |work=CalMatters |language=en-US |quote="The bill Newsom signed today, combined with earlier legislation that eases restrictions on development, won’t affect the broader economic forces that make residential construction a tough sell at the moment, said Ben Metcalf, managing director of [[UC Berkeley]]’s [[Terner Center for Housing Innovation]] and the former head of the [[California Department of Housing and Community Development|state’s housing department]]. “But if costs come down and interest rates drop, you can imagine we’ve set the table for a building boom.”"}}</ref> The law, if used for the construction of SB 79 projects, is slated to increase regular usage of public transit, as well as reduce emissions, traffic congestion and accidents from automobiles.
Within UTCs, SB 79 is set to overturn or undermine local laws and propositions which restrict density levels, such as [[Proposition U]], a 1986 [[Los Angeles]] ballot initiative which limited allowable residential density outside of [[Downtown Los Angeles]] by half.<ref name=":03">{{Cite journal |last=Severen |first=Christopher |date=2023 |title=Commuting, Labor, and Housing Market Effects of Mass Transportation: Welfare and Identification |url=https://www.philadelphiafed.org/-/media/frbp/assets/working-papers/2018/wp18-14r.pdf |journal=Review of Economics and Statistics |volume=105 |issue=5 |pages=1073–1091 |doi=10.1162/rest_a_01100 |issn=0034-6535}}</ref> The law's immediate impact was not expected by commentators to blunt the effects of contemporary economic deterrence to housing construction (i.e. [[Tariffs in the second Trump administration]]), but to potentially take advantage of future market improvements favorable to construction in order to bring down the costs of housing and living.<ref>{{Cite news |last=Christopher |first=Ben |date=2025-10-10 |title=Gavin Newsom signs law overhauling local zoning to build more housing |url=https://calmatters.org/housing/2025/10/newsom-signs-massive-california-housing-overhaul/ |access-date=2025-10-13 |work=CalMatters |language=en-US |quote="The bill Newsom signed today, combined with earlier legislation that eases restrictions on development, won’t affect the broader economic forces that make residential construction a tough sell at the moment, said Ben Metcalf, managing director of [[UC Berkeley]]’s [[Terner Center for Housing Innovation]] and the former head of the [[California Department of Housing and Community Development|state’s housing department]]. “But if costs come down and interest rates drop, you can imagine we’ve set the table for a building boom.”"}}</ref> The law, if used for the construction of SB 79 projects, is slated to increase regular usage of public transit, as well as reduce emissions, traffic congestion and accidents from automobiles.

One preliminary analysis by Streets for All estimated that SB 79 would zone nearly 1.5 million new units of housing in the City of Los Angeles, enough to double the city's then-current housing stock of 1.37 million homes, with over 448,000 new units being zoned after the law's effective date of July 1, 2026, and over 1 million more units during the 7th RHNA Cycle in 2031. In addition, the analysis estimated that the law would impact 17,929 acres, or a little over 5% of city land, with over half of impacted acres previously zoned for single family homes (9,953 acres).<ref>{{Cite web |date=2025-10-15 |title=SB 79 just legalized 1.5 million new homes near transit in the City of LA |url=https://data.streetsforall.org/blog/sb79_impact/ |access-date=2025-10-16 |website=data.streetsforall.org |language=en}}</ref>


==Related legislation==
==Related legislation==

summary.reason: The change adds significant new information about the potential impact of SB 79, including specific estimates on housing units and land use.
summary.summary: Added preliminary analysis estimating SB 79 would zone nearly 1.5 million new housing units in Los Angeles, significantly increasing the city's housing stock.

summary.reason: The change adds a minor detail about the potential future benefits of the law, but does not significantly alter the understanding of the law's impact.
summary.summary: Added that SB 79's impact could be favorable to construction in order to bring down the costs of housing and living.

changes.diff:
Line 21: Line 21:
}}
}}


The '''Abundant and Affordable Homes Near Transit Act''',<ref name=":0" /> officially '''California Senate Bill 79 (SB 79)''', is a 2025 California law that legalizes the construction of multi-story multi-family housing within a half-mile of public transit stations by preempting [[local government]] control of [[zoning|land zoning]] in the intervening area.
'''California Senate Bill 79''' ('''SB 79'''), titled the '''Abundant and Affordable Homes Near Transit Act''',<ref name=":0" /> is a 2025 California law that legalizes the construction of multi-story multi-family housing within a half-mile of public transit stations by preempting [[local government]] control of [[zoning|land zoning]] in the intervening area.


SB 79 and preceding bills have been authored by state senator [[Scott Wiener]] and have been sponsored by [[California YIMBY]], a pro-housing lobbying group,<ref name="source">{{cite news |last=Dillon |first=Liam |date=January 4, 2018 |title=Get ready for a lot more housing near the Expo Line and other California transit stations if new legislation passes |url=https://www.latimes.com/politics/la-pol-ca-housing-transit-bill-20180104-story.html |accessdate=April 17, 2018 |work=Los Angeles Times}}</ref><ref name="Mercury-March">{{cite news |last1=Murphy |first1=Katy |last2=Baldassari |first2=Erin |date=March 3, 2018 |title=California gears up for a battle over single-family zoning near transit |url=https://www.mercurynews.com/2018/03/03/sb-827/ |accessdate=April 29, 2018 |work=The Mercury News}}</ref> while they have been opposed by local governments, anti-gentrification activists, and suburban homeowners. The bills are written in support of [[transit-oriented development]] in response to an [[California housing shortage|ongoing housing affordability crisis]] in California's largest urban areas.<ref name="laist">{{cite web |author=Matt Levin |date=January 31, 2020 |title=California's Most Controversial Homebuilding Bill, SB50, Just Died. What's Next? |url=https://laist.com/2020/01/31/sb50_controversial_homebuilding_bill_died_explainer.php |url-status=dead |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20200201130238/https://laist.com/2020/01/31/sb50_controversial_homebuilding_bill_died_explainer.php |archive-date=February 1, 2020 |access-date=April 20, 2020 |work=LAist}}</ref>
SB 79 and preceding bills have been authored by state senator [[Scott Wiener]] and have been sponsored by [[California YIMBY]], a pro-housing lobbying group,<ref name="source">{{cite news |last=Dillon |first=Liam |date=January 4, 2018 |title=Get ready for a lot more housing near the Expo Line and other California transit stations if new legislation passes |url=https://www.latimes.com/politics/la-pol-ca-housing-transit-bill-20180104-story.html |accessdate=April 17, 2018 |work=Los Angeles Times}}</ref><ref name="Mercury-March">{{cite news |last1=Murphy |first1=Katy |last2=Baldassari |first2=Erin |date=March 3, 2018 |title=California gears up for a battle over single-family zoning near transit |url=https://www.mercurynews.com/2018/03/03/sb-827/ |accessdate=April 29, 2018 |work=The Mercury News}}</ref> while they have been opposed by local governments, anti-gentrification activists, and suburban homeowners. The bills are written in support of [[transit-oriented development]] in response to an [[California housing shortage|ongoing housing affordability crisis]] in California's largest urban areas.<ref name="laist">{{cite web |author=Matt Levin |date=January 31, 2020 |title=California's Most Controversial Homebuilding Bill, SB50, Just Died. What's Next? |url=https://laist.com/2020/01/31/sb50_controversial_homebuilding_bill_died_explainer.php |url-status=dead |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20200201130238/https://laist.com/2020/01/31/sb50_controversial_homebuilding_bill_died_explainer.php |archive-date=February 1, 2020 |access-date=April 20, 2020 |work=LAist}}</ref>


Wiener first introduced the bill in January 2018 as '''Senate Bill 827''' ('''SB 827'''), which would have applied to areas within {{convert|1/2|mi|km|1|adj=mid|spell=in}} of frequent transit corridors, including rail stations and bus routes, as well as jobs centers. SB 827 failed to advance from the Senate Transportation and Housing Committee in April 2018, effectively killing it.{{r|NYT-Apr}} In 2019 and 2020, Senator Wiener attempted to pass '''California Senate Bill 50''' ('''SB 50'''), a revised successor to SB 827, multiple times both in committee and on the senate floor, culminating in an unsuccessful floor vote on January 31, 2020, which resulted in the bill's demise.<ref name="auto">{{Cite web |url=https://www.paloaltoonline.com/news/2020/01/29/sb-50-hangs-by-a-thread-after-failing-to-get-needed-votes-in-the-senate |title=Contentious housing bill SB 50 dies on the Senate floor |last=Sheyner |first=Gennady |website=www.paloaltoonline.com |language=en |access-date=February 14, 2020}}</ref> A light-touch version, '''Senate Bill 902 (SB 902)''', passed the Senate in 2020 but died in the Assembly Appropriations Committee. SB 79 was introduced by Wiener in the 2025 session, where it passed in both houses.
Wiener first introduced the bill in January 2018 as '''Senate Bill 827''' ('''SB 827'''), which would have applied to areas within {{convert|1/2|mi|km|1|adj=mid|spell=in}} of frequent transit corridors, including rail stations and bus routes, as well as jobs centers. SB 827 failed to advance from the Senate Transportation and Housing Committee in April 2018, effectively killing it.{{r|NYT-Apr}} In 2019 and 2020, Senator Wiener attempted to pass '''California Senate Bill 50''' ('''SB 50'''), a revised successor to SB 827, multiple times both in committee and on the senate floor, culminating in an unsuccessful floor vote on January 31, 2020, which resulted in the bill's demise.<ref name="auto">{{Cite web |url=https://www.paloaltoonline.com/news/2020/01/29/sb-50-hangs-by-a-thread-after-failing-to-get-needed-votes-in-the-senate |title=Contentious housing bill SB 50 dies on the Senate floor |last=Sheyner |first=Gennady |website=www.paloaltoonline.com |language=en |access-date=February 14, 2020}}</ref> A light-touch version, '''Senate Bill 902''' ('''SB 902'''), passed the Senate in 2020 but died in the Assembly Appropriations Committee. SB 79 was introduced by Wiener in the 2025 session, where it passed in both houses.


The 2021 [[California HOME Act]] (drafted by Wiener) and 2022 [[California Assembly Bill 2097 (2022)|AB 2097]] (drafted by [[Laura Friedman]]), both signed into law by Newsom, accomplished some of the same aims as SB 827 and SB 50, by allowing lot splits of single-family houses up to four units per lot (regardless of single-family zoning) as well as banning parking minimums within a half-mile of transit stops, respectively.<ref name="SB 9">{{cite web | title=SB 9: The California HOME Act | website=Focus | date=June 9, 2021 | url=https://focus.senate.ca.gov/sb9 | access-date=November 4, 2024}}</ref><ref name="AB 2097 summary">{{cite web | title=AB-2097 Residential, commercial, or other development types: parking requirements. | website=California Legislative Information | date=2022 | url=https://leginfo.legislature.ca.gov/faces/billNavClient.xhtml?bill_id=202120220AB2097 | access-date=November 4, 2024}}</ref>
The 2021 [[California HOME Act]] (drafted by Wiener) and 2022 [[California Assembly Bill 2097 (2022)|AB 2097]] (drafted by [[Laura Friedman]]), both signed into law by Newsom, accomplished some of the same aims as SB 827 and SB 50, by allowing lot splits of single-family houses up to four units per lot (regardless of single-family zoning) as well as banning parking minimums within a half-mile of transit stops, respectively.<ref name="SB 9">{{cite web | title=SB 9: The California HOME Act | website=Focus | date=June 9, 2021 | url=https://focus.senate.ca.gov/sb9 | access-date=November 4, 2024}}</ref><ref name="AB 2097 summary">{{cite web | title=AB-2097 Residential, commercial, or other development types: parking requirements. | website=California Legislative Information | date=2022 | url=https://leginfo.legislature.ca.gov/faces/billNavClient.xhtml?bill_id=202120220AB2097 | access-date=November 4, 2024}}</ref>

summary.reason: The change is purely formatting and does not affect the content or meaning of the text.
summary.summary: Minor formatting change to the title of Senate Bill 902, with no new information added.

changes.diff:
Line 43: Line 43:

Multiple state (and, in some cases, local) laws have been enacted since 1980 to reduce the shortage, with a greater number of reforms being passed since 2017: some reduced the fees and bureaucracy involved in creating [[Secondary suite|ADUs]], lot splits and duplexes, while others have added fees to real-estate document recording to finance low-income housing; others required localities to allow higher density development closer to public transit.<ref>See the section on [[California housing shortage#State|State Responses]] for more detail about the above-mentioned legislation, with all sources cited.</ref>
Multiple state (and, in some cases, local) laws have been enacted since 1980 to reduce the shortage, with a greater number of reforms being passed since 2017: some reduced the fees and bureaucracy involved in creating [[Secondary suite|ADUs]], lot splits and duplexes, while others have added fees to real-estate document recording to finance low-income housing; others required localities to allow higher density development closer to public transit.<ref>See the section on [[California housing shortage#State|State Responses]] for more detail about the above-mentioned legislation, with all sources cited.</ref>

When [[2018 California gubernatorial election|running for governor in 2017]], Newsom announced his target of constructing 3.5 million homes statewide by 2025.<ref name="NPR_2021-06-08">{{cite news |last=Rosalsky |first=Greg |date=2021-06-08 |title=How California Homelessness Became A Crisis |url=https://www.npr.org/sections/money/2021/06/08/1003982733/squalor-behind-the-golden-gate-confronting-californias-homelessness-crisis |newspaper=[[NPR]] |quote=A 2016 study by McKinsey Global Institute estimated that California needs 3.5 million new housing units by 2025 to deal with its chronic housing shortage. Yet new housing construction has only slowed since then, despite Gov. Gavin Newsom's campaign promise to lead an effort to produce those 3.5 million units.}}</ref>{{r|McKinsey_3.5_by_2025}} This would require a quadrupling of the current rate of building to almost 400,000 units per year, a rate the state has not experienced since 1954.<ref name="Newsom_3.5M_by_2025">{{cite news |last=Dillon |first=Liam |date=October 23, 2017 |title=Gavin Newsom calls for California to nearly quadruple its annual housing production |url=http://www.latimes.com/politics/essential/la-pol-ca-essential-politics-updates-newsom-calls-for-california-to-nearly-1508790304-htmlstory.html |url-status=live |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180202220514/http://www.latimes.com/politics/essential/la-pol-ca-essential-politics-updates-newsom-calls-for-california-to-nearly-1508790304-htmlstory.html |archive-date=2018-02-02 |access-date=2018-06-01 |newspaper=[[Los Angeles Times]]}}</ref> {{r|LAT_Newsom_threat|p=1|q=As a candidate, Newsom called for the building of 3.5 million new homes in the state by 2025, an amount that would more than quadruple the current rate of production.}}<ref>{{Cite web |date=2019-09-02 |title=Editorial: Gavin Newsom tells Southern California to plan for housing. A lot more housing |url=https://www.latimes.com/opinion/story/2019-08-30/gavin-newsom-fair-share-housing-southern-california |access-date=2019-09-04 |website=Los Angeles Times |language=en-US}}</ref> By 2023, only about 650,000 permits were taken out for new homes since Newsom had taken office. He revised his 2026 target downward to 2.5 million homes when running for re-election in 2022.<ref>{{Cite news |last=Bollag |first=Sophia |title=Newsom set a major housing goal for 2025. Here's how far short the state has fallen |url=https://www.sfchronicle.com/politics/article/gavin-newsom-housing-record-19971316.php |archive-url=http://web.archive.org/web/20250818073943/https://www.sfchronicle.com/politics/article/gavin-newsom-housing-record-19971316.php |archive-date=2025-08-18 |access-date=2025-10-14 |work=San Francisco Chronicle |language=en}}</ref>


=== Transit-oriented development ===
=== Transit-oriented development ===
Line 211: Line 213:
Density bonuses are applied to the distance of a project adjacent to a station:
Density bonuses are applied to the distance of a project adjacent to a station:


* within 200 feet of the station: 4-4.5 [[Floor area ratio|FAR]], 120-160 units/ac, 85-95 ft
* within 200 feet of the station: 4-4.5 [[Floor area ratio|FAR]], 120-160 units/ac, 85-95 ft;
* within 1/4 miles of the station: 3-3.5 FAR 100-120 units/ac, 65-75 ft
* within 1/4 miles of the station: 3-3.5 FAR 100-120 units/ac, 65-75 ft;
* within 1/2 miles of the station: 2.5-3 FAR, 60-100 units/ac, 55-65 ft<ref name=":3">{{Cite web |last=Vcard |first=Download Caroline Guibert Chase |title=Governor Newsom Approves SB 79: High-Density Transit-Oriented Housing Development Projects {{!}} Legal Alerts |url=https://www.allenmatkins.com/real-ideas/governor-newsom-approves-sb-79-high-density-transit-oriented-housing-development-projects.html |access-date=2025-10-12 |website=Allen Matkins - Governor Newsom Approves SB 79: High-Density Transit-Oriented Housing Development Projects {{!}} Legal Alerts |language=en}}</ref>
* within 1/2 miles of the station: 2.5-3 FAR, 60-100 units/ac, 55-65 ft.<ref name=":3">{{Cite web |last=Vcard |first=Download Caroline Guibert Chase |title=Governor Newsom Approves SB 79: High-Density Transit-Oriented Housing Development Projects {{!}} Legal Alerts |url=https://www.allenmatkins.com/real-ideas/governor-newsom-approves-sb-79-high-density-transit-oriented-housing-development-projects.html |access-date=2025-10-12 |website=Allen Matkins - Governor Newsom Approves SB 79: High-Density Transit-Oriented Housing Development Projects {{!}} Legal Alerts |language=en}}</ref>
Under [[California Assembly Bill 2097 (2022)|AB 2097 (2022)]], parking mandates are prohibited statewide within 0.5 miles (0.8 km) of a major transit stop for most development projects, including SB 79-eligible projects in urban transit counties.


=== Tenant and disaster protections ===
=== Tenant and disaster protections ===
Line 263: Line 266:
The mayor of [[Beverly Hills]], who engaged in a broadcast debate with Senator Wiener, questioned why Senate Bill 50 would necessarily impact [[Southern California]] while exempting several affluent yet sparsely populated Bay Area counties.<ref>{{Cite web |url=http://www.foxandhoundsdaily.com/2019/05/sb50-sticking-it-to-socal/ |title=SB50: Sticking it to SoCal |date=May 14, 2019 |website=Fox&Hounds |access-date=February 14, 2020}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news |url=https://calmatters.org/housing/2019/10/podcast-opposites-of-california-housing-debate/ |title=Podcast: A debate between polar opposites over the California housing crisis |date=October 31, 2019 |website=CalMatters |language=en-US |access-date=February 14, 2020|last1=Levin |first1=Matt }}</ref> The bill faced opposition from local governments around the state who objected to how the bill would usurp local land use authority.<ref>{{Cite web |url=https://event-newsenterprise.com/local-governments-relieved-as-sb50-fails-again/ |title=Local governments relieved as SB50 fails again |last=Young |first=David N. |date=February 12, 2020 |language=en-US |access-date=February 14, 2020}}</ref> Some mayors endorsed the bill.<ref>{{Cite news |url=https://www.citylab.com/equity/2019/04/silicon-valley-california-affordable-housing-sb50-palo-alto/587773/ |title=An Island of Silicon Valley Affordability Says Yes to More Housing |last=Bliss |first=Laura |newspaper=Bloomberg.com |date=April 24, 2019 |language=en |access-date=February 14, 2020}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web |url=https://sf.curbed.com/2019/1/18/18188416/sb-50-transit-housing-wiener-tubbs-liccardo |title=San Jose and Stockton mayors boost transit-housing plan |website=sf.curbed.com |date=January 18, 2019 |language=en |access-date=February 14, 2020}}</ref>
The mayor of [[Beverly Hills]], who engaged in a broadcast debate with Senator Wiener, questioned why Senate Bill 50 would necessarily impact [[Southern California]] while exempting several affluent yet sparsely populated Bay Area counties.<ref>{{Cite web |url=http://www.foxandhoundsdaily.com/2019/05/sb50-sticking-it-to-socal/ |title=SB50: Sticking it to SoCal |date=May 14, 2019 |website=Fox&Hounds |access-date=February 14, 2020}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news |url=https://calmatters.org/housing/2019/10/podcast-opposites-of-california-housing-debate/ |title=Podcast: A debate between polar opposites over the California housing crisis |date=October 31, 2019 |website=CalMatters |language=en-US |access-date=February 14, 2020|last1=Levin |first1=Matt }}</ref> The bill faced opposition from local governments around the state who objected to how the bill would usurp local land use authority.<ref>{{Cite web |url=https://event-newsenterprise.com/local-governments-relieved-as-sb50-fails-again/ |title=Local governments relieved as SB50 fails again |last=Young |first=David N. |date=February 12, 2020 |language=en-US |access-date=February 14, 2020}}</ref> Some mayors endorsed the bill.<ref>{{Cite news |url=https://www.citylab.com/equity/2019/04/silicon-valley-california-affordable-housing-sb50-palo-alto/587773/ |title=An Island of Silicon Valley Affordability Says Yes to More Housing |last=Bliss |first=Laura |newspaper=Bloomberg.com |date=April 24, 2019 |language=en |access-date=February 14, 2020}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web |url=https://sf.curbed.com/2019/1/18/18188416/sb-50-transit-housing-wiener-tubbs-liccardo |title=San Jose and Stockton mayors boost transit-housing plan |website=sf.curbed.com |date=January 18, 2019 |language=en |access-date=February 14, 2020}}</ref>


Senator Wiener said the passage of an anti rent-gouging bill in the previous year hindered the leverage for passing Senate Bill 50.<ref name = "laist"></ref>
Senator Wiener said the passage of an anti rent-gouging bill in the previous year hindered the leverage for passing Senate Bill 50.<ref name = "laist"/>


A ''[[Los Angeles Times]]'' columnist said lawmakers from the greater Los Angeles area delegation were responsible for the demise of Senate Bill 50, and that the fight "had nothing to do with partisan politics" but instead was "all about geography"<ref>{{Cite web |url=https://www.latimes.com/california/story/2020-02-03/skelton-sb50-housing-california-legislation-fails-los-angeles-county |title=Column: Suburban sprawl wins again in the battle against California's housing crisis |date=February 3, 2020 |website=Los Angeles Times |language=en-US |access-date=February 14, 2020}}</ref> while a ''[[Curbed]]'' columnist said opposition from a statewide coalition of affordable housing advocacy organizations was responsible for the defeat of Senate Bill 50.<ref>{{Cite web |url=https://www.curbed.com/2020/2/7/21125100/sb-50-california-bill-fail |title=The real reason California's upzoning bill failed |last=Walker |first=Alissa |date=February 7, 2020 |website=Curbed |language=en |access-date=February 14, 2020}}</ref>
A ''[[Los Angeles Times]]'' columnist said lawmakers from the greater Los Angeles area delegation were responsible for the demise of Senate Bill 50, and that the fight "had nothing to do with partisan politics" but instead was "all about geography"<ref>{{Cite web |url=https://www.latimes.com/california/story/2020-02-03/skelton-sb50-housing-california-legislation-fails-los-angeles-county |title=Column: Suburban sprawl wins again in the battle against California's housing crisis |date=February 3, 2020 |website=Los Angeles Times |language=en-US |access-date=February 14, 2020}}</ref> while a ''[[Curbed]]'' columnist said opposition from a statewide coalition of affordable housing advocacy organizations was responsible for the defeat of Senate Bill 50.<ref>{{Cite web |url=https://www.curbed.com/2020/2/7/21125100/sb-50-california-bill-fail |title=The real reason California's upzoning bill failed |last=Walker |first=Alissa |date=February 7, 2020 |website=Curbed |language=en |access-date=February 14, 2020}}</ref>
Line 284: Line 287:

==Impact==
==Impact==
Within UTCs, SB 79 is set to overturn or undermine local laws and propositions which restrict density levels, such as [[Proposition U]], a 1986 [[Los Angeles]] ballot initiative which limited allowable residential density outside of [[Downtown Los Angeles]] by half.<ref name=":03">{{Cite journal |last=Severen |first=Christopher |date=2023 |title=Commuting, Labor, and Housing Market Effects of Mass Transportation: Welfare and Identification |url=https://www.philadelphiafed.org/-/media/frbp/assets/working-papers/2018/wp18-14r.pdf |journal=Review of Economics and Statistics |volume=105 |issue=5 |pages=1073–1091 |doi=10.1162/rest_a_01100 |issn=0034-6535}}</ref> The law's immediate impact was not expected by commentators to blunt the effects of contemporary economic deterrences to housing construction (i.e. [[Tariffs in the second Trump administration]]), but to potentially take advantage of future market improvements.<ref>{{Cite news |last=Christopher |first=Ben |date=2025-10-10 |title=Gavin Newsom signs law overhauling local zoning to build more housing |url=https://calmatters.org/housing/2025/10/newsom-signs-massive-california-housing-overhaul/ |access-date=2025-10-13 |work=CalMatters |language=en-US |quote="The bill Newsom signed today, combined with earlier legislation that eases restrictions on development, won’t affect the broader economic forces that make residential construction a tough sell at the moment, said Ben Metcalf, managing director of [[UC Berkeley]]’s [[Terner Center for Housing Innovation]] and the former head of the [[California Department of Housing and Community Development|state’s housing department]]. “But if costs come down and interest rates drop, you can imagine we’ve set the table for a building boom.”"}}</ref>
Within UTCs, SB 79 is set to overturn or undermine local laws and propositions which restrict density levels, such as [[Proposition U]], a 1986 [[Los Angeles]] ballot initiative which limited allowable residential density outside of [[Downtown Los Angeles]] by half.<ref name=":03">{{Cite journal |last=Severen |first=Christopher |date=2023 |title=Commuting, Labor, and Housing Market Effects of Mass Transportation: Welfare and Identification |url=https://www.philadelphiafed.org/-/media/frbp/assets/working-papers/2018/wp18-14r.pdf |journal=Review of Economics and Statistics |volume=105 |issue=5 |pages=1073–1091 |doi=10.1162/rest_a_01100 |issn=0034-6535}}</ref> The law's immediate impact was not expected by commentators to blunt the effects of contemporary economic deterrence to housing construction (i.e. [[Tariffs in the second Trump administration]]), but to potentially take advantage of future market improvements.<ref>{{Cite news |last=Christopher |first=Ben |date=2025-10-10 |title=Gavin Newsom signs law overhauling local zoning to build more housing |url=https://calmatters.org/housing/2025/10/newsom-signs-massive-california-housing-overhaul/ |access-date=2025-10-13 |work=CalMatters |language=en-US |quote="The bill Newsom signed today, combined with earlier legislation that eases restrictions on development, won’t affect the broader economic forces that make residential construction a tough sell at the moment, said Ben Metcalf, managing director of [[UC Berkeley]]’s [[Terner Center for Housing Innovation]] and the former head of the [[California Department of Housing and Community Development|state’s housing department]]. “But if costs come down and interest rates drop, you can imagine we’ve set the table for a building boom.”"}}</ref> The law, if used for the construction of SB 79 projects, is slated to increase regular usage of public transit, as well as reduce emissions, traffic congestion and accidents from automobiles.


==Related legislation==
==Related legislation==

changes.diff:
Line 141: Line 141:

== Provisions ==
== Provisions ==
⚫
[[File:Millbrae station from Millbrae Avenue, July 2018.JPG|thumb|[[Millbrae station]] ([[Bay Area Rapid Transit|BART]] and [[Caltrain]] intermodal station, photo taken July 2018), an example of a "Tier 1" station near which SB 79-eligible housing could potentially be built.]]The law allows eligibility for [[California Senate Bill 35 (2017)#SB 423|SB 423]] streamlining for affordable housing projects and adopts SB 423's requirement to hire skilled and trained workers for SB 79 project which is higher than 85 feet in height. In addition, SB 79 projects constructed on transit agency-owned land have the option to either hire unionized workers or enter into a direct contract with labor unions. Finally, the law excludes hotel development projects from its provisions.<ref name=":1" />


=== Approval process ===
⚫
The law can also be paired with the [[California Density Bonus Law]], the California Housing Crisis Act of 2019 (SB 330), and the [[California Housing Accountability Act]] to further streamline approval. The law does not create a [[California Environmental Quality Act|CEQA]]-exempt or by-right pathway for qualifying projects.<ref name=":3" />
⚫
[[File:Millbrae station from Millbrae Avenue, July 2018.JPG|thumb|[[Millbrae station]] ([[Bay Area Rapid Transit|BART]] and [[Caltrain]] intermodal station, photo taken July 2018), an example of a "Tier 1" station near which SB 79-eligible housing could potentially be built.]]While not mandating ministerial approval of housing projects by itself, SB 79 allows eligibility for [[California Senate Bill 35 (2017)#SB 423|SB 35 (2017)/SB 423 (2023)]]-compliant ministerial streamlining for affordable housing projects. It adopts SB 423's requirement to hire skilled and trained workers for SB 79 project which is higher than 85 feet in height. In addition, SB 79 projects constructed on transit agency-owned land have the option to either hire unionized workers or enter into a direct contract with labor unions. The law excludes hotel development projects from its provisions.<ref name=":1" />

⚫
The law can also be paired with the [[California Density Bonus Law]], the California Housing Crisis Act of 2019 (SB 330), and the [[California Housing Accountability Act]] to further streamline approval. The law does not create a [[California Environmental Quality Act|CEQA]]-exempt or by-right pathway for qualifying projects.<ref name=":3" /> An SB 79 project, whether residential or mixed-use, may also be built in a commercial or light-industrial zone under SB 35/SB 423 (or the project must separately qualify under [[Affordable Housing and High Road Jobs Act|SB 6]]).


=== Areas and tiers of applicability ===
=== Areas and tiers of applicability ===

summary.reason: The change clarifies the relationship between SB 79 and SB 35/SB 423, adding new information about project eligibility and zoning options.
summary.summary: Clarified that SB 79 allows SB 35/SB 423-compliant ministerial streamlining for affordable housing projects and added that SB 79 projects may be built in commercial or light-industrial zones under SB 35/SB 423.

Line 147: Line 147:
=== Areas and tiers of applicability ===
=== Areas and tiers of applicability ===
[[File:SB_79_urban_transit_counties.svg|thumb|Map of counties of California which are deemed urban transit counties under California Senate Bill 79 (2025).]]
[[File:SB_79_urban_transit_counties.svg|thumb|Map of counties of California which are deemed urban transit counties under California Senate Bill 79 (2025).]]
The law applies only to jurisdictions within designated "urban transit counties" which contain 16 or more rail stations, currently [[Alameda County, California|Alameda]], [[Los Angeles County, California|Los Angeles]], [[Orange County, California|Orange]], [[Sacramento County, California|Sacramento]], [[Santa Clara County, California|Santa Clara]], [[San Diego County, California|San Diego]], [[San Francisco]], [[San Mateo County, California|San Mateo]]. Initially inclusive of 15 or more rail stations, the threshold was raised by amendment to 16 rail stations to exclude [[Contra Costa County, California|Contra Costa]], [[Sonoma County, California|Sonoma]] and [[Marin County, California|Marin]], which were initially included, based on arguments by local officials that the bill would increase density along fire evacuation zones and put residents at risk.<ref>{{Cite web |last=Staff |first=T. R. D. |date=2025-09-18 |title=Contra Costa County scores only transit-oriented upzoning exemption |url=https://therealdeal.com/san-francisco/2025/09/18/contra-costa-exempt-from-californias-transit-related-upzoning/ |access-date=2025-10-10 |website=The Real Deal |language=en}}</ref> In addition, within urban transit counties, SB 79 is applied in full to projects within cities of 35,000 in population, while SB 79 projects within cities of less than 35,000 in population shall only be built within 1/4 of a mile of an eligible station.<ref>{{Cite web |last=Golub |first=Daniel R. |last2=Maclean |first2=Chelsea |last3=Sterling |first3=Will |last4=Muñoz |first4=Franklin B. |title=California Gov. Gavin Newsom Signs SB 79, Unlocking Higher Residential Density Near Transit {{!}} Insights {{!}} Holland & Knight |url=https://www.hklaw.com/en/insights/publications/2025/10/california-gov-gavin-newsom-signs-sb-79 |access-date=2025-10-12 |website=www.hklaw.com |language=en}}</ref>
The law applies only to jurisdictions within designated "urban transit counties" (UTC) which contain 16 or more rail stations, currently [[Alameda County, California|Alameda]], [[Los Angeles County, California|Los Angeles]], [[Orange County, California|Orange]], [[Sacramento County, California|Sacramento]], [[Santa Clara County, California|Santa Clara]], [[San Diego County, California|San Diego]], [[San Francisco]], [[San Mateo County, California|San Mateo]]. Initially inclusive of 15 or more rail stations, the threshold was raised by amendment to 16 rail stations to exclude [[Contra Costa County, California|Contra Costa]], [[Sonoma County, California|Sonoma]] and [[Marin County, California|Marin]], which were initially included, based on arguments by local officials that the bill would increase density along fire evacuation zones and put residents at risk.<ref>{{Cite web |last=Staff |first=T. R. D. |date=2025-09-18 |title=Contra Costa County scores only transit-oriented upzoning exemption |url=https://therealdeal.com/san-francisco/2025/09/18/contra-costa-exempt-from-californias-transit-related-upzoning/ |access-date=2025-10-10 |website=The Real Deal |language=en}}</ref> In addition, within urban transit counties, SB 79 is applied in full to projects within cities of 35,000 in population, while SB 79 projects within cities of less than 35,000 in population shall only be built within 1/4 of a mile of an eligible station.<ref>{{Cite web |last=Golub |first=Daniel R. |last2=Maclean |first2=Chelsea |last3=Sterling |first3=Will |last4=Muñoz |first4=Franklin B. |title=California Gov. Gavin Newsom Signs SB 79, Unlocking Higher Residential Density Near Transit {{!}} Insights {{!}} Holland & Knight |url=https://www.hklaw.com/en/insights/publications/2025/10/california-gov-gavin-newsom-signs-sb-79 |access-date=2025-10-12 |website=www.hklaw.com |language=en}}</ref>


The law creates two tiers of jurisdictions, with SB 79-eligible housing being eligible for certain height limits depending on distance of the nearby type of transit station:
The law creates two tiers of jurisdictions, with SB 79-eligible housing being eligible for certain height limits depending on distance of the nearby type of transit station:
Line 233: Line 233:
=== Effective date and enforcement ===
=== Effective date and enforcement ===
[[File:Carlsbad Village Station 3.jpg|thumb|[[Carlsbad Village station]] (on the [[North County Transit District|NCTD]] [[Coaster (rail service)|COASTER]], photo taken October 2010), an example of a "Tier 3" station which would have been potentially eligible to build SB 79 housing nearby prior to removal of the Tier in committee. ]]
[[File:Carlsbad Village Station 3.jpg|thumb|[[Carlsbad Village station]] (on the [[North County Transit District|NCTD]] [[Coaster (rail service)|COASTER]], photo taken October 2010), an example of a "Tier 3" station which would have been potentially eligible to build SB 79 housing nearby prior to removal of the Tier in committee. ]]
The law comes into effect in local agencies on July 1, 2026 (unless a local agency adopts an [[California Department of Housing and Community Development|HCD]]-compliant implementing ordinance or local transit-oriented development alternative plan prior to the effective date), while implementation of SB 79 in unincorporated areas of a county would be delayed until the 7th [[Regional Housing Needs Assessment]] allocation cycle in 2031. In addition, implementation of SB 79 in station areas which have at least 50% of SB 79 eligibility in 6th Cycle rezoning, as well as in various sensitive areas (historic districts, low resource areas and fire- or sea level rise-prone areas), would be delayed until one year following adoption of the 7th Cycle, provided that the local agency has adopted an ordinance indicating the site’s exclusion.
The law comes into effect in local agencies on July 1, 2026 (unless a local agency adopts an [[California Department of Housing and Community Development|HCD]]-compliant implementing ordinance or local transit-oriented development alternative plan prior to the effective date), while implementation of SB 79 in unincorporated areas of a county would be delayed until the 7th [[Regional Housing Needs Assessment]] allocation cycle in 2031. In addition, implementation of SB 79 in station areas which have at least 50% of SB 79 eligibility in 6th Cycle rezoning, as well as in various sensitive areas (historic districts, low resource areas and fire- or sea level rise-prone areas), would be delayed until one year following adoption of the 7th Cycle, provided that the local agency has adopted an ordinance indicating the site’s exclusion.

Within urban transit counties, SB 79 will apply in full to any station which is fully planned or under construction by January 1, 2026, including to [[Orange County, California|Orange County]] upon completion of the [[OC Streetcar]], slated for Q1 2026. SB 79 will only apply partially to any county which fully plans a minimum 16th rail station and achieves urban transit county status after January 1, 2026, with only heavy rail, light rail, and eligible commuter rail stations being covered to the exclusion of BRT stations.<ref>{{Cite web |last=Gray |first=M. Nolan |last2=Eckhouse |first2=Aaron |date=2025-10-12 |title=Everything You Need To Know About SB 79 |url=https://mnolangray.substack.com/p/everything-you-need-to-know-about |access-date=2025-10-12 |website=Arbitrary Lines}}</ref>


The HCD shall be responsible for enforcement of compliance, and is empowered to suspend any non-compliant local implementing ordinance. The HCD may refer any local government found in violation of SB 79 to the [[Attorney General of California]] for prosecution. The Attorney General may also levy a fine of $10,000-$50,000 per month upon the offending local government until the HCD finds the local government in compliance.
The HCD shall be responsible for enforcement of compliance, and is empowered to suspend any non-compliant local implementing ordinance. The HCD may refer any local government found in violation of SB 79 to the [[Attorney General of California]] for prosecution. The Attorney General may also levy a fine of $10,000-$50,000 per month upon the offending local government until the HCD finds the local government in compliance.

summary.reason: The change adds significant new information about the application of SB 79 to stations planned or under construction by January 1, 2026, including specific details about Orange County and the OC Streetcar.
summary.summary: Added details about SB 79 applying in full to stations planned or under construction by January 1, 2026, including Orange County's OC Streetcar.

changes.diff:
Line 32: Line 32:

==Background==
==Background==
⚫
{{Main|California housing shortage|Transit-oriented development}}
[[File:Donner Lofts Affordable Housing, San Jose, California (45376171252).jpg|thumb|Multi-story apartment building designated for affordable housing in downtown [[San Jose, California|San Jose]]. ]]
[[File:Donner Lofts Affordable Housing, San Jose, California (45376171252).jpg|thumb|Multi-story apartment building designated for affordable housing in downtown [[San Jose, California|San Jose]]. ]]

=== California housing shortage ===
⚫
{{Main|California housing shortage|}}
California housing costs are among the most unaffordable in the United States. In 2018, the median [[San Jose, California|San Jose]] home cost 10 times the median household income; [[Los Angeles]] homes cost 9.5 times; [[San Francisco]] homes cost 8.9 times; [[San Diego]] homes cost 8.1 times.<ref name="harv">[https://www.jchs.harvard.edu/sites/default/files/Harvard_JCHS_State_of_the_Nations_Housing_2018.pdf “The State of the Nation’s Housing 2018”] “Joint Center for Housing Studies of Harvard University” Retrieved March 13, 2019.</ref> California is the most expensive state to rent in, in the [[United States]].<ref>Hoffower, Hillary [https://www.businessinsider.com/salary-afford-rent-every-state-us-ranked-2018-7#2-california-50 “The Salary you need to afford rent in every state, ranked”]”Business Insider” November 26, 2018. Retrieved March 12, 2019.</ref>

California has had a housing shortage since 1970 and ranks 49th among 50 states for housing units per capita.<ref name="McKinsey">[https://www.mckinsey.com/~/media/mckinsey/featured%20insights/urbanization/closing%20californias%20housing%20gap/closing-californias-housing-gap-full-report.ashx “A Tool Kit To Close California’s Housing Gap: 3.5 Million Homes by 2025”] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20181104220006/https://www.mckinsey.com/~/media/McKinsey/Featured%20Insights/Urbanization/Closing%20Californias%20housing%20gap/Closing-Californias-housing-gap-Full-report.ashx|date=November 4, 2018}} Accessed March 8, 2019.</ref> The problem has worsened following the [[Great Recession]] as housing development fell to 40,000 units in 2009 and has not reached pre-recession levels.<ref name="LA2">Dillon, Liam [https://www.latimes.com/politics/la-pol-ca-housing-legislation-signed-20170929-htmlstory.html “Gov. Brown just signed 15 housing bills. Here’s how that’s supposed to help the affordability crisis”]”Los Angeles Times,” September 29, 2017. Retrieved March 12, 2019</ref> California needs approximately 180,000 units per year to match current growth.<ref name="McKinsey" /> Slow housing development combined with high housing demand has increased housing costs in every city in California.

The state’s high rent prices have translated into increased [[homelessness]], more households spending half their income on housing, and an exodus of low and middle income households leaving to states with lower [[cost of living]].<ref>Del Valle, Gaby [https://www.vox.com/the-goods/2018/12/14/18131047/homelessness-rent-burden-study “How rising rents contribute to homelessness”]”Vox” December 14, 2018. Retrieved March 13, 2019.</ref> The housing shortage negatively impacts the [[Economy of California]].

Multiple state (and, in some cases, local) laws have been enacted since 1980 to reduce the shortage, with a greater number of reforms being passed since 2017: some reduced the fees and bureaucracy involved in creating [[Secondary suite|ADUs]], lot splits and duplexes, while others have added fees to real-estate document recording to finance low-income housing; others required localities to allow higher density development closer to public transit.<ref>See the section on [[California housing shortage#State|State Responses]] for more detail about the above-mentioned legislation, with all sources cited.</ref>

=== Transit-oriented development ===
{{Main|Transit-oriented development}}
In 2008, [[Arnold Schwarzenegger]] signed [[Sustainable Communities and Climate Protection Act of 2008|Senate Bill 375]], which encourages transit-oriented development to reduce vehicle miles travelled in the state and to address [[climate change]]. The bill was created to help achieve the greenhouse gas reduction goals of the 2006 bill [[Global Warming Solutions Act of 2006|Assembly Bill 32]].
In 2008, [[Arnold Schwarzenegger]] signed [[Sustainable Communities and Climate Protection Act of 2008|Senate Bill 375]], which encourages transit-oriented development to reduce vehicle miles travelled in the state and to address [[climate change]]. The bill was created to help achieve the greenhouse gas reduction goals of the 2006 bill [[Global Warming Solutions Act of 2006|Assembly Bill 32]].


Line 271: Line 283:
=== ADU construction ===
=== ADU construction ===
{{Main|California Senate Bill 1534 (1982)#Amendments}}
{{Main|California Senate Bill 1534 (1982)#Amendments}}

In 2016, California lawmakers removed local barriers to [[Secondary suite|accessory dwelling unit (ADU)]] construction by passing Senate Bill 1069. This was later updated in 2017 with Senate Bill 229 and Assembly Bill 494. These bills modified [[single-family zoning]] throughout California by requiring speedy local approval of up to 1,200 square foot secondary units on all residential property in California, including land zoned for single-family homes.<ref>{{cite web|url = https://nextcity.org/daily/entry/california-adu-applications-skyrocket-after-regulatory-reform | title = California ADU Applications Skyrocket After Regulatory Reform | work = Nextcity}}</ref> In 2019, the law was updated with Assembly Bill 68 to allow up to 500 of the 1,200 square feet to be designated a "junior accessory dwelling unit"; some commentators said this amounted to de facto triplex zoning throughout the state.<ref>{{cite web|url = https://www.curbed.com/2019/10/11/20909545/adus-development-california-real-estate-housing-shortage | title = Will California's new ADU laws create a backyard building boom? | work = Curbed| date = October 11, 2019 }}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url = https://lbpost.com/longbeachize/addison-ab-68-single-family-zoning-triplex | title = Opinion: Finally, Governor signs AB 68 into law, effectively ending single-family zoning statewide | work = Long Beach Post}}</ref>
In 2016, California lawmakers removed local barriers to [[Secondary suite|accessory dwelling unit (ADU)]] construction by passing Senate Bill 1069. This was later updated in 2017 with Senate Bill 229 and Assembly Bill 494. These bills modified [[single-family zoning]] throughout California by requiring speedy local approval of up to 1,200 square foot secondary units on all residential property in California, including land zoned for single-family homes.<ref>{{cite web|url = https://nextcity.org/daily/entry/california-adu-applications-skyrocket-after-regulatory-reform | title = California ADU Applications Skyrocket After Regulatory Reform | work = Nextcity}}</ref> In 2019, the law was updated with Assembly Bill 68 to allow up to 500 of the 1,200 square feet to be designated a "junior accessory dwelling unit"; some commentators said this amounted to de facto triplex zoning throughout the state.<ref>{{cite web|url = https://www.curbed.com/2019/10/11/20909545/adus-development-california-real-estate-housing-shortage | title = Will California's new ADU laws create a backyard building boom? | work = Curbed| date = October 11, 2019 }}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url = https://lbpost.com/longbeachize/addison-ab-68-single-family-zoning-triplex | title = Opinion: Finally, Governor signs AB 68 into law, effectively ending single-family zoning statewide | work = Long Beach Post}}</ref>

summary.reason: The change adds significant new information about the California housing shortage, including statistics, causes, and impacts.
summary.summary: Added detailed information about the California housing shortage, including high housing costs relative to income, the long-standing shortage, and its economic and social impacts.
